content:
Introduction

Potassium (K+) plays a critical role in maintaining cellular function, nerve transmission, and muscle contraction.  After oral ingestion or intravenous (IV) administration, potassium is largely stored intracellularly and then steadily excreted in the urine.  Hyperkalemia (serum potassium >5.0 mEq/L) and hypokalemia (serum potassium <3.5 mEq/L) require prompt recognition and management to prevent complications that may be potentially life-threatening.

Pathophysiology



The body maintains a total potassium reservoir of approximately 3,000-4,000 mEq depending on body weight.  Approximately 98% of the body's potassium resides within cells with a concentration of approximately 140 mEq/L, whereas extracellular concentrations are normally only 3.5-5 mEq/L.  The marked disparity in potassium distribution across cellular membranes is the major determinant of the resting membrane potential (RMP).  The RMP is integral for action potentials (eg, nerve transmission, muscle contraction) and is actively maintained by the Na+/K+-ATPase pump, which expels 3 Na+ for every 2 K+ it imports) (

figure 1
).  The RMP is altered by both hyperkalemia (depolarization increases excitability) and hypokalemia (hyperpolarization decreases excitability) (
figure 2
).



Potassium homeostasis is maintained through a delicate balance involving:

Gastrointestinal (GI) handling



Dietary sources provide 40-150 mEq/day of potassium, primarily absorbed in the small intestine (through passive diffusion).  Fecal potassium losses via the colon are normally minimal (5-10 mEq/day) because the healthy colon reabsorbs much more potassium than it secretes.  However, diarrhea can significantly increase losses.

Cellular distribution



Distribution of potassium is highly sensitive to factors that cause potassium to shift between intracellular and extracellular compartments.  Factors include pH changes (eg, acidosis drives potassium out of cells), hormonal influences (eg, insulin promotes potassium uptake), and medications affecting pump function (eg, digoxin inhibits Na+/K+-ATPase) or cellular permeability (eg, albuterol promotes potassium uptake).

Renal handling



The kidneys are the primary regulators of potassium balance, responsible for 90% of its excretion.  Potassium is freely filtered in the glomerulus, with most reabsorbed in the proximal tubule and thick ascending limb.  Fine-tuning occurs in the distal nephron, namely principal cells in collecting ducts; these cells secrete potassium in response to elevations in serum potassium, distal sodium delivery, and aldosterone (

figure 3
).



Disruptions in any of these processes can lead to hyperkalemia or hypokalemia.

Hyperkalemia

Presentation and etiologies



Depending on the severity and chronicity, hyperkalemia may be asymptomatic (eg, found incidentally) or symptomatic.  Hyperkalemia is usually asymptomatic until potassium rises to ‚â•6.5 mEq/L, but acute hyperkalemia may cause symptoms at lower levels.  Symptoms include ascending muscle weakness with flaccid paralysis, and palpitations due to cardiac arrhythmias.  Etiologies include decreased renal excretion, shifting of potassium from the intracellular to extracellular space, and increased potassium intake.



Decreased renal excretion



Impaired renal potassium excretion is by far the most common cause of hyperkalemia.  Major precipitating factors include the following:



  • Reduced glomerular filtration rate impairs potassium excretion due to reduced distal sodium and water delivery.  It can be seen in the following instances:
    • Acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD)
    • Chronic nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use (reduced renal blood flow due to intraglomerular hemodynamic changes)
  • Decreased aldosterone level impairs distal potassium secretion.  It can be due to the following:
    • Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism:  Decreased renin secretion leads to reduced aldosterone production.  Examples include CKD (particularly due to diabetes mellitus), chronic NSAID use (multifactorial), and calcineurin inhibitors (eg, tacrolimus).
    • Hyperreninemic hypoaldosteronism:  Decreased aldosterone production occurs independently from renin (renin increases as an attempt to compensate).  Examples include primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) and certain medications such as ACE inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (eg, spironolactone), and chronic heparin use (eg, inhibits aldosterone synthase).


Transcellular shifts



Potassium shifts out of cells in various conditions, including:



  • Metabolic acidosis:  Excess hydrogen ions (H‚Å∫) enter cells in exchange for potassium leaving.
  • Insulin deficiency:  Reduced insulin prevents cellular uptake of potassium.
  • Tissue breakdown:  Hemolysis, rhabdomyolysis, and tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) release intracellular potassium.
  • Medications:  Beta blockers and digoxin toxicity promote shifting of potassium out of cells.


Increased intake



Excessive intake of potassium-containing foods or supplements predisposes to hyperkalemia.  It is usually seen only in patients with significantly impaired renal function.  Otherwise, a phenomenon known as potassium adaptation allows increased urinary potassium secretion to offset increased intake (ie, one can ingest 400 mEq/day without developing hyperkalemia).



A summary of medications that cause hyperkalemia is provided in this table (

üìä View Table: table 1
).

Evaluation



Pseudohyperkalemia



The first step is to exclude pseudohyperkalemia, which is artificially high serum potassium caused by potassium release from cells during blood collection.  Common causes include mechanical trauma during venipuncture (releases potassium from hemolyzed erythrocytes) and repeated fist clenching during blood drawing (releases potassium from muscle cells).  A new blood sample should be collected.



True hyperkalemia



Evaluation of true hyperkalemia often occurs concurrently with treatment, particularly in severe cases due to the time sensitivity of potentially life-threatening complications.  A detailed history should be obtained, including dietary habits (eg, potassium salt substitutes), underlying diseases (eg, CKD), and medication use (eg, ACE inhibitors, potassium-sparing diuretics, NSAIDs).  An ECG should be obtained promptly to assess for changes, which increase in significance corresponding to the severity of hyperkalemia (

figure 4
).



Metabolic acidosis, if present, should be noted because it can cause a transient elevation in serum potassium that resolves with treatment of acidosis.  Particular attention should be paid to renal function because AKI and CKD predispose to hyperkalemia.  Chronicity should be assessed, if possible, because acute hyperkalemia is usually more dangerous than chronic hyperkalemia given there is less time for cellular adaptation.  Further evaluation depends on the clinical picture; for example, in a hypotensive patient, a morning cortisol level can be checked to evaluate for primary adrenal insufficiency.

Management



The urgency of hyperkalemia treatment is based on the severity of clinical manifestations, degree of hyperkalemia, and underlying cause.



Hyperkalemic emergency



Hyperkalemic emergency is defined by any 1 of the following:



  • Serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L
  • Muscle weakness, ECG changes, cardiac arrhythmias
  • Rapidly increasing serum potassium (eg, rhabdomyolysis, TLS)


Hyperkalemic emergency is treated with both temporizing and definitive measures.  Temporizing measures aim to quickly reduce the effects of high potassium (particularly on the heart) but do not remove excess potassium.  This allows time for definitive measures to reduce total body potassium.



Temporizing measures



  • Cardiac membrane stabilization:
    • IV calcium administration counteracts the effects of hyperkalemia on the heart.  It is typically most useful when significant ECG changes are present (eg, QRS widening) but may also be given without these changes.
  • Shifting potassium into cells:
    • Insulin and glucose:  IV administration of insulin (typically 10 units) promotes cellular potassium uptake.  IV glucose is co-administered (25-50 grams) to prevent hypoglycemia.
    • Beta-agonists:  Nebulized albuterol stimulates beta-receptors, promoting cellular potassium uptake.
    • Sodium bicarbonate is useful in cases of metabolic acidosis because it alkalinizes the blood, thereby shifting potassium into cells.


Given the temporary effects of these medications (calcium effects last 30-60 min and insulin effects last 4-6 hr), close monitoring of serum potassium and ECG changes is required.



Definitive measures



Measures to enhance potassium elimination include the following:



  • IV fluids are used if prerenal azotemia is suspected.
  • Loop or thiazide diuretics are used to increase renal potassium excretion (avoid in volume depletion).
  • Cation-exchange resins bind potassium in the GI tract (effect takes hours).  Patiromer (
    figure 5
    ) and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate are preferred over sodium polystyrene sulfonate given the risk for volume overload and intestinal necrosis.
  • Hemodialysis is warranted in severe or refractory cases, typically for renal failure.


Patients who do not meet the criteria for hyperkalemic emergency can have serum potassium lowered less urgently, with focus placed on definitive measures without temporizing interventions.  This includes those with chronic, mild (‚â§5.5 mEq/L) or moderate (5.6-6.5 mEq/L) hyperkalemia without acute symptoms, often seen in CKD or medication-induced cases.  Key strategies include medication adjustment, dietary potassium restriction, and treatment of underlying conditions.  For persistent hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with CKD maintained with ACE inhibitors or ARBs for renoprotection, chronic use of potassium binders should be considered.



A summary of hyperkalemia management is provided in this table (

üìä View Table: table 2
).

Hypokalemia

Presentation and etiologies



As with hyperkalemia, hypokalemia may be asymptomatic (eg, found incidentally) or symptomatic.  Symptoms of hypokalemia include muscle cramps, weakness, fatigue, constipation, and in severe cases, paralysis or arrhythmias.  Etiologies include increased losses, shifting of potassium from the extracellular to intracellular space, and decreased intake.



Increased losses



Potassium loss can occur through the kidneys, GI tract, or sweat glands.



  • Renal losses:
    • Diuretics:  Thiazides and loop diuretics increase urinary potassium excretion.
    • Hyperaldosteronism:  Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome) and Cushing syndrome, in addition to secondary hyperaldosteronism (eg, due to heart failure or cirrhosis), enhance potassium excretion.
    • Renal tubular disorders:
      • Type 1 (distal) renal tubular acidosis:  Impaired distal H‚Å∫ secretion leads to acidosis and increased potassium excretion to maintain electroneutrality.
      • Type 2 (proximal) renal tubular acidosis:  Bicarbonate wasting leads to acidosis and secondary hyperaldosteronism (increased potassium excretion).
      • Bartter and Gitelman syndromes:  Defective Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫-2Cl (Bartter) and Na-Cl (Gitelman) cotransporters mimic loop and thiazide diuretic use, respectively; this leads to potassium losses.
  • GI losses
    • Diarrhea:  A loss of potassium-rich colonic secretions directly causes hypokalemia.
    • Vomiting or nasogastric suctioning:  Gastric secretions contain minimal potassium; instead, hypokalemia occurs indirectly via secondary renal mechanisms:
      • A loss of hydrogen-rich gastric secretions leads to metabolic alkalosis, increasing renally filtered bicarbonate.  Bicarbonate in the tubules increases distal sodium delivery, promoting potassium secretion (hypovolemia-induced aldosterone release also plays a role).
  • Sweat losses:  excessive sweating, as in strenuous exercise in hot environments or conditions like cystic fibrosis


Transcellular shifts



Potassium shifts into cells in various conditions, including:



  • Metabolic alkalosis:  H‚Å∫ ions move out of cells in exchange for potassium.
  • Increased insulin levels:  Insulin therapy, especially during refeeding in malnourished patients, enhances cellular uptake of potassium.
  • Beta-adrenergic stimulation:  Epinephrine and beta-agonists (eg, albuterol) promote cellular uptake of potassium.
  • Increased erythrocyte production:  Acute increases in hematopoiesis (eg, after treating megaloblastic anemia) can cause potassium uptake by new cells.


Decreased intake



Insufficient dietary potassium intake is uncommon but may occur in patients with eating disorders or on strict diets.

Evaluation



A comprehensive history should be obtained, including dietary habits (eg, extreme dieting), medication use (eg, diuretics), and change in bowel habits (eg, diarrhea).  An ECG should be obtained to assess for changes, which include T-wave inversion/flattening, ST depression, and prominent U waves (

figure 6
); tachyarrhythmias are also commonly seen.  Serum magnesium should be checked because it helps maintain normal potassium levels (eg, maintaining Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫-ATPase function, preventing renal potassium wasting); its deficiency can cause hypokalemia.  Hypokalemia evaluation requires determining if potassium losses are due to renal or GI losses, assessing acid-base status and other causes of transcellular shifts.



Distinguishing between renal and GI losses



If not obvious by clinical history, further evaluation can be performed to distinguish between renal and GI losses.  Renal potassium excretion can be quantified either via 24-hour collection (most accurate) or spot urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio (most practical).  An elevated urinary potassium (>25-30 mEq/day) suggests hypokalemia is due to renal losses, whereas a low urinary potassium indicates a renal compensatory response to GI losses.  Calculation of the transtubular potassium gradient ([K‚Å∫]urine √ó serum osmolality / [K‚Å∫]serum √ó urine osmolality) may also be helpful.  Further evaluation depends on the clinical picture; for example, in a hypertensive patient, renin and aldosterone levels should be checked to evaluate for potential etiologies (

Causes of hypertension hypokalemia
).



Assessing acid-base status and other causes of transcellular shifts



In some cases, hypokalemia may be due transcellular potassium shifting in combination with or in the absence of renal/GI losses.  This can be seen in significant alkalosis; therefore, evaluation includes assessment of serum bicarbonate, albumin, and arterial/venous blood gas analysis.  Other conditions that can cause hypokalemia include thyrotoxicosis and rare conditions like hypokalemic periodic paralysis.

Management



Hypokalemia can occasionally be attributed solely to alkalosis that resolves following restoration of a normal pH (eg, acute respiratory alkalosis during a panic attack).  However, in most cases there are renal or GI losses that require potassium repletion.  In addition, patients often have coexisting hypomagnesemia due to common precipitating factors (eg, diarrhea, diuretic use).  In these cases, the focus should be on correcting serum magnesium because hypokalemia can otherwise be refractory to potassium replacement.  The urgency of hypokalemia correction depends on the severity of hypokalemia (eg, severe if <3.0 mEq/L) and degree of symptoms (eg, tachyarrhythmias, paralysis).



Potassium chloride, administered either orally or IV, is usually preferred because of its efficacy and the added benefit of addressing chloride depletion (often coexists with hypokalemia).



  • In mild to moderate hypokalemia (3.0-3.4 mEq/L), 10 mEq of potassium chloride leads to a sustained increase in serum potassium by approximately 0.1 mEq/L, in the absence of ongoing losses.
  • In severe cases, the rise can be much less significant and require larger doses.  IV repletion rates typically should not exceed 10-20 mEq/hr given the risk for precipitating hyperkalemia because there can be a delay in potassium movement into cells.


Continued potassium replacement for several days may be required in severe cases due to marked total body potassium depletion.



The underlying cause of hyperkalemia should be addressed to prevent recurrence.  Chronic diarrhea should be managed with antidiarrheal medications when appropriate.  Diuretic-induced hypokalemia can be addressed either by daily potassium chloride supplementation or the addition of potassium-sparing diuretics (eg, spironolactone, amiloride).

Summary



Potassium homeostasis is crucial for normal cellular function, particularly in nerve and muscle tissue.  The body maintains this balance through complex interactions involving gastrointestinal absorption, cellular distribution, and renal excretion.  Disruptions in these mechanisms can lead to hyperkalemia or hypokalemia, both of which can have serious clinical consequences.  Effective management of potassium disorders requires a thorough understanding of underlying pathophysiology, prompt recognition through careful clinical evaluation, and appropriate laboratory testing.

Hyperkalemia



Management involves temporizing measures to stabilize cardiac membranes (ie, intravenous calcium) and shifting potassium intracellularly (eg, insulin, glucose); definitive measures aim to eliminate excess potassium from the body.  Long-term management focuses on addressing underlying causes, which may include medication adjustments, treatment of renal dysfunction, or management of endocrine disorders.  For patients with chronic hyperkalemia, especially those with chronic kidney disease, ongoing use of potassium binders may be necessary.

Hypokalemia



Management primarily involves potassium repletion, with the urgency and route of administration determined by the severity of the deficit and presence of symptoms.  Concurrent magnesium deficiency must be addressed to ensure effective potassium repletion.  Long-term management of hypokalemia involves identifying and treating the underlying cause, which may include adjusting diuretic therapy, managing endocrine disorders, or addressing chronic gastrointestinal losses.  Ongoing potassium supplementation or use of potassium-sparing diuretics may be necessary.
